questions.text: A 30-year-old alcoholic male presents with h/o of yellowish discoloration of the skin and mucous membrane. What will favor the diagnosis of alcoholic hepatitis over viral and toxin-related hepatitis?

options.label: C
options.text: ALT greater than or equal to the AST

questions.correct_answer: A. AST-to-ALT ratio of at least 2:1
questions.explanation:
Solution:

AST-to-ALT ratio of at least 2:1 Alcoholic hepatitis can be differentiated from viral and toxin-related hepatitis by the pattern of the aminotransferases: patients with alcoholic hepatitis typically have an AST-to-ALT ratio of at least 2:1, and the AST level rarely exceeds 300 U/L.

options.label: B
options.text: Chronic infection with hepatitis B virus (HBV)

options.label: C
options.text: Chronic infection with hepatitis C virus (HCV)

options.label: D
options.text: Acute infection with hepatitis E virus (HEV)

questions.correct_answer: C. Chronic infection with hepatitis C virus (HCV)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chronic infection with hepatitis C virus (HCV) Chronic infection with the hepatitis C virus (HCV) is an essential comorbidity in the progression of alcoholic liver disease to cirrhosis in regular Even light to moderate alcohol intake of 15–30 g/d increases the risk of cirrhosis and hepatocellular cancer in HCV-infected individuals. Patients with alcoholic liver injury and HCV infection develop decompensated liver disease at a younger age and have poorer overall survival .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, D: Not reported. Option: B: No established association.

questions.text: A 28-year male gives a history of alcohol consumption of about 60 g/day for 8 years. What is the initial and most common histologic response to hepatotoxic stimuli?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fatty liver Fatty liver is the initial and most common histological response to hepatotoxic stimuli, including excessive alcohol ingestion. Fat accumulation within the Peri venular hepatocytes coincides with the location of alcohol dehydrogenase, the major enzyme responsible for alcohol metabolism. In men, 40–80 g/d of ethanol produces fatty liver; 160 g/d for 10–20 years causes hepatitis or cirrhosis. Only 15% of alcoholics develop alcoholic liver disease.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B: Less common and usually late changes. 160 g/d for 10–20 years causes hepatitis or cirrhosis. Alcoholic hepatitis is thought to be a precursor to the development of cirrhosis. Option: D: Late complication.

questions.text: The transition between fatty liver and the development of alcoholic hepatitis is blurred. All of the following are the hallmarks of alcoholic hepatitis EXCEPT:

options.label: C
options.text: Fat accumulation within the Peri venular hepatocytes

questions.correct_answer: C. Fat accumulation within the Peri venular hepatocytes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fat accumulation within the Peri venular hepatocytes The accumulation of fat within the Peri venular hepatocytes is a feature of a Fatty liver.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B, D: The hallmark of alcoholic hepatitis is hepatocyte injury characterized by ballooning degeneration , spotty necrosis , polymorphonuclear infiltrate , and fibrosis in the Peri venular and perisinusoidal space of Disse. Mallory-Denk bodies are often present in florid cases but are neither specific nor necessary to establish the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about alcohol-mediated liver injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Alcoholic hepatitis is a precursor to the development of cirrhosis

options.label: B
options.text: Fatty liver is potentially reversible with cessation of drinking

options.label: C
options.text: Alcoholic hepatitis is potentially irreversible even with cessation of drinking

options.label: D
options.text: Cirrhosis is present in up to 50% of patients with biopsy-proven alcoholic hepatitis

questions.correct_answer: C. Alcoholic hepatitis is potentially irreversible even with cessation of drinking
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alcoholic hepatitis is potentially irreversible even with cessation of drinking Alcoholic hepatitis, like fatty liver, is potentially reversible with cessation of drinking. Complete abstinence from alcohol is the cornerstone of treating alcoholic liver disease. Regardless of the initial clinical presentation, improved survival and the potential for reversal of histologic injury are associated with total avoidance of alcohol ingestion.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: Alcoholic hepatitis is thought to be a precursor to the development of cirrhosis. Option: B: True. Option: D: Cirrhosis is present in up to 50% of patients with biopsy-proven alcoholic hepatitis; its regression is uncertain, even with abstention.

questions.text: A 32-year female is diagnosed with alcoholic hepatitis. In all of the following conditions, prednisone should be given EXCEPT?

Solution:

Presence of pancreatitis Exclusion criteria include active gastrointestinal bleeding, renal failure, or pancreatitis. Patients with infection can be concurrently treated with antibiotics and steroids.

Option: D: Women with encephalopathy from severe alcoholic hepatitis may be excellent candidates for glucocorticoids.
